author: Split lane

review: First, the remote isn't infrared, it's some sort of wireless signal that is unable to penetrate the TV.  So if the dongle is behind the TV and you're in front, the remote doesn't work at all even if you're 1 inch away.  So I got an HDMI extension cable that lets the Roku dangle beneath the TV.  Now the remote works, but only within a 3 foot range.  You have to get out of your chair and get right up to the Roku for the remote to work.  And, assuming it's powered by your TV's usb, it takes a couple minutes to boot.  Then it takes another minute or so to start Netflix.  Then you have to walk right up to it to get the remote to work, and even then it takes several minutes to navigate because 90% of the time when you touch the arrow buttons nothing happens, and then suddenly the 'stick' and the pointer moves around on the screen way past what you want.  So you have to hit the arrow the other way about 10x before the pointer starts moving back, and repeat many, many times until you finally click what you want.Because of this screwy remote, it took about 15 minutes just to input my wifi ssid and password.  And don't even think about trying to type search results.On top of it, you cannot play local media.  I have vanilla h.264 files stored on my NAS.  I tried installing the plex media server on my Synology NAS (since there's an app for the player), but the Roku says every video file is an "uncompatible file type".  Then I installed some streaming software on my PC.  Same thing.  Roku can't play any of the video files.
